This year marks 400 years since the first African slaves were brought to Virginia in chains and yet many African Americans are still unable to visit and mourn their ancestors.  We need to preserve this history and culture. That is why the #BurialGroundsAct matters.

This injustice is not unique to Richmond or Virginia. I have come to realize this is the tragic reality for African American cemeteries throughout the country. These sites deserve funding for identification, preservation and restoration efforts.

I first became aware of this injustice when I was a state delegate as I witnessed this neglect in my own background. Richmond's Evergreen and East End Cemeteries are culturally and historically important to our Af Am community but are in dire need of preservation and restoration.

Why are so many of these burial grounds in a state of disrepair or utterly inaccessible? Local laws segregated burial grounds by race. These burial sites were often confined to marginal property or remote areas, and frequently failed to receive monetary support or maintenance.

I wanted to share a few thoughts about why this is so important. For far too long, African-American burial grounds have suffered neglect and abuse which is unacceptable. These are some of our most sacred spaces and they should be treated with respect and care.

Earlier today I was honored to discuss the African American Burial Grounds Network Act at a @NRDems subcommittee hearing, legislation I introduced with @RepAdams to preserve and protect the history and culture of African American burial sites.
